detailed_description: Simulates a scenario where a process or service consumes excessive CPU resources, leading to performance degradation.
Introduces a memory leak in an application or service, causing gradual memory consumption until the system becomes unresponsive.
Fills up the disk space on a node, preventing applications from writing logs, storing data, or functioning properly.
Adds artificial network latency to simulate slow network conditions and evaluate the resilience of applications.
Drops a percentage of network packets to mimic unreliable network conditions, affecting communication between services.
Causes database queries to time out, simulating network failures or high load on the database server.
Forces a service or application to crash unexpectedly, requiring recovery mechanisms to restart it.
Triggers Kubernetes to evict a pod, simulating node pressure or misconfiguration.
Alters or corrupts a critical configuration file, causing application failures or unexpected behavior.
Prevents services from resolving domain names, simulating DNS outages or misconfigurations.
Replaces a valid SSL certificate with an expired one, causing authentication and connection issues.
Introduces high disk I/O latency, impacting read/write operations and overall system performance.
Locks up critical application threads, leading to unresponsiveness and degraded performance.
Overloads a message queue or event bus, delaying message processing and causing backpressure.
Generates excessive log entries, overwhelming logging systems and making debugging difficult.
Alters user permissions to simulate a security vulnerability, potentially allowing unauthorized access.
Simulates a scenario where a critical database table remains locked due to long-running transactions, blocking other queries.
Leaves unused cloud resources running without cleanup, leading to increased costs and resource wastage.
Introduces a known security vulnerability by rolling back a patched version of an application.
Modifies the system clock to be out of sync, causing authentication failures and inconsistent timestamps in logs.
